It is indeed hard to balance progress and public welfare. The code of public safety was greatly violated as the engineers sought to break technological boundaries. Although the bridge was a magnificent structure, its construction failed to consider the safety of the public. The engineers used their knowledge and skill wrongly because it was not for the betterment of the society.
  −   −
B
  −
Several stakeholders were violated by these ethical violations in a myriad of ways.
  −
Stakeholder 1
  −
The public were a major stakeholder who was violated. The inappropriate and cheap construction of the bridge endangered human lives, even though it sought to break the limits of technological advancements.
  −
Stakeholder 2
  −
Engineers are also major stakeholders who were affected by the collapse of the bridge. There trustworthiness was considerably affected owing to the failure of their fellow engineers.
  −   −
What Should Have Been Done Differently So As To Prevent Any Ethical Violations
  −
The ethical violations could have been avoided in several ways. Firstly, the designers should have considered previous designs, which, although were expensive, were durable and sustainable. Moisseiff should have designed a stable bridge that would consider the safety of the public and avoid unnecessary wastage of funds. Although it would mean that the project would be expensive, the result would have eventually been cheaper, considering the amount wasted in the destroyed project. Alternatively, innovative techniques are necessary to ensure that there is progress. Although it may be risky, there is always headway for future engineers as they explore new techniques.
  −        
The [[ontology]] of ethics is about value-bearing things or properties, i.e. the kind of things or stuff referred to by ethical propositions. Non-descriptivists and non-cognitivists believe that ethics does not need a specific ontology, since ethical propositions do not refer. This is known as an anti-realist position. Realists on the other hand must explain what kind of entities, properties or states are relevant for ethics, how they have value, and why they guide and motivate our actions.<ref>Miller, C. (2009). The Conditions of Moral Realism. The Journal of Philosophical Research, 34, 123-155.</ref>
